briefing.opening: Good morning. We will now begin the climate briefing for January 10, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Intensification of Extreme Weather Events in Korea
sections.content: In Korea, extreme weather events caused by climate change are intensifying, and their unpredictability is increasing. Notably, the scale of disasters is unusual, with two large-scale wildfires, each the size of 140 football fields, occurring annually [1]. Furthermore, extreme weather phenomena are frequently observed regardless of the season, such as typhoon-level strong winds in January and heavy snow advisories issued across the country [5]. These phenomena clearly demonstrate that climate change is no longer a distant future problem but a present reality threatening our lives.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ğŸŒ International Climate Disasters and Vulnerability
sections.content: Internationally, catastrophic situations due to climate change continue, with increasing threats particularly to vulnerable populations. In Southern Brazil in 2024, extreme rainfall and large-scale floods, influenced by El NiÃ±o and climate change, caused immense damage [11]. Similarly, floods are occurring in the Marin region amidst ongoing climate change denial [8]. Indigenous tribes in the Pacific Northwest of America are facing severe challenges to their survival and cultural preservation, as their millennia-old way of life is threatened by climate change [10].

sections.title: ğŸŒ±ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Efforts to Respond to the Climate Crisis
sections.content: Domestically, tangible efforts to address the climate crisis are ongoing. The Seoul Energy Dream Center and the Korea Climate & Environment Network have strengthened their cooperation to jointly respond to the climate crisis [2]. Furthermore, Pyeongchang County is expanding its irrigation facility support project to prepare for droughts, thereby enhancing the community's adaptability [3]. Seoul National University, the top carbon emitter among single institutions in Seoul, has stated that there are ample ways to reduce carbon emissions and has announced specific reduction efforts [4].

sections.title: ğŸŒğŸŒ± International Climate Change Response Policies and Funding
sections.content: In the international community, new policy introductions and negotiation efforts are underway to address climate change. In Hawaii, a tourism tax for climate change response has been implemented, presenting a new model for securing funding for sustainable tourism and environmental protection [6]. Additionally, Australia's COP31 chief negotiator plans to lobby oil-producing nations for a phased reduction of fossil fuels, indicating significant diplomatic efforts for a global decarbonization transition [16]. These movements demonstrate the international community's resolve to secure the financial basis and political will necessary for climate change response.

sections.title: ğŸ“°ğŸŒ Challenges in Climate Change Awareness and Public Discourse
sections.content: In the process of public awareness and discourse regarding climate change, diverse perspectives and debates still exist. The case of Berkshire County, which experienced its coldest December in 15 years, reminds us that local weather phenomena do not negate climate change, emphasizing the importance of understanding climate science [7]. Meanwhile, Bill Maher has made candid remarks about climate change and private jet use [13, 14, 15], and Whitney Cummings has pointed out the hypocrisy of liberals regarding climate change [9], indicating active discussions on climate action and individual responsibility. There are also growing calls to stop actions that exacerbate climate change to make America healthy again [12], demonstrating that climate change is a societal issue.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing has once again underscored the severe reality of climate change, alongside various domestic and international response efforts, and the importance of continuous public discourse. We must actively address these changes and gather wisdom for a sustainable future. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.title: 'Was it a typhoon in January?' Strong winds 'blowing'... Heavy snow advisories in various parts of the country
articles.original_title: â€˜1ì›”ì— íƒœí’ ì™”ë‚˜â€™ ê°•í’ â€˜ìŒ©ìŒ©â€™Â·Â·Â·ì „êµ­ ê³³ê³³ ëŒ€ì„¤ íŠ¹ë³´
articles.description: On the 10th, a resident walking a dog in Goyang City was startled by strong winds. Yonhap News. As a trough (low pressure system) passed over the northern part of South Korea, strong winds, as if a typhoon had arrived, blew across the country on the 10th. Strong winds are expected to continue along the southern and eastern coasts until the 11th, and along the western coast and Jeju for the time being. Heavy snow advisories have been issued for some areas, including the mountainous regions of Gangwon, southern inland Chungnam, and northern Jeonnam, with snow expected until the 11th.Â·Â·Â·
